security: Disclosing Abram Chayes's security approval for discussing NSC 5412/2 matters on a need-to-know basis could expose sensitive operational details and liaison contacts with Covert Action Staff. The document reveals, 'The request for CHAYES' clearance was a 'Blanket' request to permit discussion with him of NSC 5412/2 matters on a need-to-know basis.'
summary: A memo details information from a newspaper column that Abram Chayes and Llewellyn Thompson were responsible for Lee Harvey Oswald's return to the U.S. from the Soviet Union in 1962 and summarizes security-related information on Chayes and Samuel Wise, including their possible connections to CIA projects.
summary_one_paragraph: This memorandum, dated January 29, 1954, compiles information related to Lee Harvey Oswald's case, focusing on Abram Chayes's and Llewellyn Thompson's alleged role in facilitating Oswald's return to the United States from the Soviet Union in 1962, as reported in a newspaper column. It outlines Chayes's security approvals for liaison contact with J. Foster Collins and Archibald Roosevelt, Jr., regarding NSC 5412/2 matters, and highlights his controversial stance on passport regulations. The memo also delves into Samuel Wise's background, including his potential CIA employment, involvement with project AEACTIVE, and association with William Orville Munsell, who was security disapproved due to questionable loyalties.
title: THE LEE HARVEY OSWALD CASE #351164
